H0.text: To control population size, trees like oaks and walnuts depend upon squirrels.

H1.text: To pollinate their flowers is why trees such as oaks and walnuts depend upon squirrels.

H2.text: To remove dead wood is why trees like oaks and walnuts depend upon squirrels.

H3.text: To aid in seed distribution, trees such as oaks and walnuts depend upon squirrels.

A4.text: Some species of squirrel selectively excise the embryos from the acorns that they store, meaning that the food store lasts longer and that the acorns will never germinate.

A5.text: Animals including squirrels and jays – Eurasian jays in the Old World, blue jays in North America – feed on acorns, and are important agents of seed dispersal as they carry the acorns away and bury many of them as food stores.

A6.text: Rodents may also disperse seeds when the presence of secondary metabolites in ripe fruits causes them to spit out certain seeds rather than consuming them.
